newsArray.title: BBC Sport: Everton make approach to sign Brighton player after Â£23m+ development
creator: George Overhill
newsArray.description: Everton are â€œkeenâ€ on signing Steven Alzate from Brighton and have already been in touch over a move, according to BBC Sport. Simon Stone reported via Twitter Wednesday (30 August) that the Colombian international â€œwill be allowed to leaveâ€ after the Seagulls brought in Carlos Baleba, with Wolves, Sevilla and Fiorentina also interested. In an ... The post BBC Sport: Everton make approach to sign Brighton player after Â£23m+ development appeared first on Goodison News.
newsArray.content: Simon Stone reported via Wednesday (30 August) that the Colombian international â€œwill be allowed to leaveâ€ after the Seagulls brought in Carlos Baleba, with Wolves, Sevilla and Fiorentina also interested. In an update on the BBC Sport website Stone added that following the Â£23.2million deal for Baleba both the Toffees and Wolves have already made approaches to Brighton for Alzate, 24, but the Serie A and La Liga options would also come with European football. Everton are before the window shuts after completing a move for Â£25.7m striker Beto from Udinese. Central midfield doesnâ€™t appear to be an obvious priority based on the current state of Sean Dycheâ€™s squad but Tom Davies has left this summer and there is always the threat of late developments around Amadou Onana on deadline day. Alex Iwobi has emerged as potential departure following long delays over the Nigerian internationalâ€™s new contract at Goodison Park, and Dyche was thought to still want wide options as it is with Demarai Gray also . Alzate had already fallen down the pecking order at Brighton prior to this summer, having just returned from a loan in Belgium with Standard Liege, and the mega-money sale of Moises Caicedo to Chelsea hasnâ€™t opened the door for more football at the Amex for him. It has been an absolute slog once more during the window but Dyche has seen his squad boosted by five arrivals, with all but one coming in attacking areas. However, he has experienced injury crises in multiple positions during his time on Merseyside already so is clearly minded to pick up cheap reinforcements where they are available. If Alzate is looking to add to his 43 Premier League appearances then Wolvesâ€™ own financial pressures should prevent them from easily beating the Toffees to this deal, although the overseas options might win the day. His versatility could be a useful option for Dyche later in the season and it sounds like a late push is now in progress.

newsArray.title: Christian Dailly: Cafu, chronic pain and quantum physics with the Dundee United hero who always â€˜felt differentâ€™
creator: Alan Temple
newsArray.description: Dailly reflected on his playing career, and new endeavours, with Courier Sport.
newsArray.content: Christian Dailly was ready to sign the contract. Another two years under the watchful eye of Dundee United icon Paul Sturrock at Southend United. Dailly would be 41 years of age by the time that deal expired but, as a health fanatic enjoying a splendid autumn to his career, there was little doubt that he possessed the longevity. â€œI was fit and playing well,â€ Dailly told . â€œBut I was really into my studies and it was difficult to balance everything â€” my head was in the literature and it felt like a jigsaw I wanted to devote myself to putting together. â€œI said to and the chairman, â€œIâ€™ve actually changed my mind on the way down. Iâ€™m not going to sign the contract,â€ and I retired on the spot!â€ Dailly had become completely engrossed in a sports science degree. He had undertaken the first two years while still playing, and was determined to give the final three years his undivided attention. This was no mere Plan B; break glass in case of failure to become a coach or pundit. He had found a calling. In the years since his retirement, Dailly has leapt headlong into cutting-edge research on aerobic fitness, strength and nutrition. coached athletics for a time, even working with Team GB representatives. He sought to educate on the dangers of â€œno pain, no gainâ€ overtraining. He now works with the general public after creating Zone 1 Health. â€œWe have seen people go into diabetes remission, go from having chronic pain to being pain-free,â€ Dailly continues. â€œWeâ€™ve got a guy who recently did his second . Before that, he had two heart attacks and was scared to do any exercise. â€œI have the same passion as I ever did working with athletes, so donâ€™t miss that side of it.â€ Dailly is likely to be the only interviewee to discuss research on Neanderthal heel-bones and their relevance to long-distance running. Or how the human body is akin to self-regulating complex weather systems. Or to profess an interest in quantum physics. â€œI like to find out how things function,â€ he smiles. â€œItâ€™s good fun. â€œItâ€™s a bit unusual to have quantum physics books by your bed before football matches, like I did. People are looking at you saying, â€œreally?â€ But I enjoyed them.â€ Not the footballing archetype, certainly. â€œI definitely felt different,â€ continued Dailly. â€œNot better or worse. I just felt like I was always looking after myself. It definitely made me a little but more isolated â€” but I was okay with that. That was who I was. â€œEveryone was alright with me but you had all the players â€” all these different interactions and relationships â€” and I was But thatâ€™s maybe why I could captain teams.â€ He added: â€œI was too young to captain , if Iâ€™m honest. But I went on to captain every team I played for, so maybe there is something about being â€œover thereâ€ that allowed me to speak and act freely.â€ Daillyâ€™s curiosity has always been present. But it did not extend to questioning his peers as he emerged through the youth ranks at Dundee United as a fresh-faced 16-year-old. â€œI was inherently good and would think, â€œthis person is my boss so he will definitely know the right thing to doâ€,â€ recalled Dailly, who scored in each of his first three games for the club while, in his words, â€œstill playing on instinctâ€. â€œWith a scientific mind, I would go back and question everything I was told.â€ . He scored 21 goals, lifted the 1994 Scottish Cup, was relegated, made captain, unmade captain, promoted and sold to Derby County for Â£1million. Eventful. By the time he departed for Pride Park, Dailly was a fine centre-back. He would represent Scotland 67 times, play at the 1998 World Cup, win five major honours and reach the Uefa Cup final with Rangers in 2008. But he still wonders how his career may have panned out if he had remained that waspish, instinctive striker who closed down Ally Maxwell at Hampden Park, admitting he felt â€œover-coachedâ€ with â€œThere are parts of me that ended up better, but when I just played,â€ he continued. â€œThere is a different world where I stayed that striker. I think I was over-coached, albeit with the best of intentions. I took everything as rules.â€ And he would love to see emerging youngsters emboldened to retain their natural flair and problem-solving ability. â€œOne thing I learned about coaching â€” and I took this on board myself â€” is not to coach rules,â€ he continued. â€œI think of strikers I played with during my career. Guys like Ally McCoist, and Kris Boyd all did what they wanted. They ran where they thought the ball was going! They didnâ€™t follow rules; their game was a natural evolution. â€œOne of the biggest problems in sport, generally, is that coaches can be far too prescriptive and ruin people. Telling people there is a â€œcorrectâ€ running style, or a way to play football, or an amount of touches you should take. â€œYouâ€™ve got to let people figure things out.â€ At this point, Dailly reserves a special mention for his former Scotland manager â€œ for that,â€ added Dailly. â€œIt didnâ€™t matter if you were playing against Cafu â€” heâ€™d say, â€œyouâ€™re better than him, run him all day and show him!â€ â€œHe was telling me that from the age of 14, when he was my manager with Scotland schoolboys. Schoolboy games? The World Cup? â€œJust you run, Christianâ€. It was so much fun. Pure freedom.â€ Chatting to in a suite at Hampden Park, scene of THAT triumph in 1994, Dailly appears genuinely taken aback when reminded that 2024 will mark 30 years since Time flies, and all that. Daillyâ€™s tireless harrying of Maxwell created the sparking wild celebrations among the Arabs as their interminable wait to lift the famous old trophy ended. â€œThe memory is so vivid to me,â€ Dailly adds. â€œI can still remember making the decision to close down Ally Maxwell and that vision of my shot trickling across the goal-line and bouncing off the post; that panic, thinking, â€œitâ€™s not going to go in.â€ â€œSeeing Brewster come in and all the fans in the corner going mad was amazing. It was so special to take the trophy back to Dundee after all those years. It was a great time, and really well deserved.â€ He smiled: â€œIâ€™ve actually watched that game back a couple of times. I donâ€™t generally watch many games back â€” I should have done that more in my career; I should have analysed and learned â€” but Iâ€™ve made an exception for that one!â€

Der Deadline Day ist schon eine Achterbahnfahrt, die auÃŸergewÃ¶hnliches Format hat. Ist ja auch schon mal passiert, dass ein Fax zwei Minuten zu spÃ¤t kamâ€¦ Aber so was von! Und wenn dabei wider Erwarten ein Problem analysiert wird, kann man den Transfer trotzdem nicht rÃ¼ckgÃ¤ngig machen. Das verbieten die Regularien. Bleibt Gravenberch oder nicht?â€œ Die sind sehr intensiv und lang. Permanent kann es extreme VerÃ¤nderungen auf dem Markt geben. Verletzungen, unerwartete VerkÃ¤ufe oder weil man eine bedeutsame KaderlÃ¼cke noch nicht schlieÃŸen konnte. Und das Zeitfenster, in dem man agieren kann, wird immer kleiner. Anspannung und Entscheidungsdruck wachsen. TÃ¤glich werden neue Szenarien durchgespielt. Durch eine hohe Transfereinnahme ist beispielsweise der Transfer eines Spielers mÃ¶glich, den man schon vorher verpflichten wollte, aber aus wirtschaftlichen GrÃ¼nden nicht konnte. Dieser Spieler ist aber vielleicht grade kurz vor dem Vertragsabschluss mit einem anderen Club. Es kann zugehen wie in einem aufgeregten Taubenschlag. Solch ein Transfer-Finale fordert permanentes Umdenken. Nehmen wir die Bayern als Beispiel. . Was tut sich bei den MÃ¼nchnern im Mittelfeld? Bleibt Gravenberch oder nicht? Wenn er wechselt: Per Leihe oder Verkauf? Nutzt man daraus resultierende Einnahmen und die Gehaltsersparnis, um vielleicht den Tuchel-Wunsch nach einer zusÃ¤tzlichen Sechs zu erfÃ¼llen? Was bedeutet dies fÃ¼r Kimmich, Goretzka und Laimer und fÃ¼r die gesamte Balance im Kader? Wenn man mÃ¶gliche Transfereinnahmen und Gehaltsersparnisse fÃ¼r beide zusammenrechnet, dÃ¼rfte ein Gesamtvolumen von Ã¼ber 80 Millionen Euro zusammenkommen. FC Bayern: â€Geld ist vorhanden und der Positionsbedarf ist groÃŸâ€œ Es wÃ¤re dann jedem klar: Geld ist vorhanden und der Positionsbedarf ist groÃŸ. Dadurch werden mÃ¶gliche AblÃ¶sen nicht geringer. GrundsÃ¤tzlich sind die Bayern aber in einer starken Position und werden kein Geschenkpaket schnÃ¼ren und nur verkaufen, wenn man interessante Alternativen umsetzen kann und zudem wirtschaftlich oder sportlich profitiert. Dreesen, HoeneÃŸ, Rummenigge und Neppe sind erfahrene Dealmaker und kennen das GeschÃ¤ft aus dem Effeff. Sicher ist eines, die KÃ¶pfe werden rauchen und natÃ¼rlich hat auch Thomas Tuchel klare Vorstellungen. Ich glaube, dass noch Unvorhergesehenes passiert, es wirtschaftliche Megadeals und mÃ¤chtig Bewegung geben wird. Bei den Saudis geht die Transferperiode noch weitere drei Wochen und das kann fÃ¼r mÃ¤chtig Unruhe sorgen. Sollte ein saudi-arabischer Verein noch an einem europÃ¤ischen Topstar interessiert sein und bereit sein, extrem zu investieren, wird es speziell. Bis zum 1. September kÃ¶nnte der abgebende Club zumindest noch reagieren, danach geht dies nicht mehr und Topclubs werden keinen wichtigen Profi mehr ziehen lassen. Ich bin mir sicher: Die nÃ¤chsten Tage wird es noch das ein oder andere Mal krÃ¤ftig knallen ( )

newsArray.title: â€˜One Of The Bestâ€™ â€“ Manchester United Star Pleads For Teammate To Stay
creator: Aaron Hindhaugh
newsArray.description: Manchester Unitedâ€™s Ella Toone has spoken to Sky Sports about how she hopes to see Mary Earps stay amid interest from other clubs around Europe. Earps has risen to stardom over the past couple of years and she largely has Sarina Wiegman to thank for that because prior to her arrival as the England manager, [â€¦]
newsArray.content: Earps has risen to stardom over the past couple of years and she largely has Sarina Wiegman to thank for that because prior to her arrival as the England manager, it was Ellie Roebuck who was the regular number one for the Lionesses and seen as the future to stopper for years to come. However, an injury to Roebuck and a huge amount of faith from Wiegman later and Earps is now widely regarded as the best goalkeeper in Womenâ€™s football and even has the trophy to prove it having been voted the best between the sticks earlier this year. Most Read on Euro Weekly News Ella Toone hopeful of Mary Earps staying at Man United While starring for England and in the Womenâ€™s Super League, it has certainly been over the last two summer tournaments in which Earps has spent the show and proven to the world just how good she is with the ball at her feet and also keeping it out of her net. Therefore, itâ€™s no surprise that an unnamed Champions League club lodged a world record bid for Earps earlier in the transfer window, just a few days after England had experienced World Cup heartache out in Australia at the hands of Spain, making it the second record bid have received this year following bid for Alessia Russo. "She's been unbelievable" Ella Toone has her fingers crossed that Mary Earps will be staying at Manchester United! ğŸ¤ğŸ”´ â€” Sky Sports WSL (@SkySportsWSL) rejected the bid out of hand and that unnamed side are yet to return with an improved offer for Earps, and her teammate, Ella Toone, is hopeful that the impressive shot-stopper will remain in Manchester. She said: â€œSheâ€™s one of the best, sheâ€™s been unbelievable in the past two tournaments for England and sheâ€™s had an unbelievable season for [Man] United. Eaprs is set to attract further attention â€œSo, sheâ€™s going to have interest in her, sheâ€™s one of the best keepers in the world at the moment. â€œIâ€™m glad weâ€™re hopefully getting to keep her and hopefully we have a successful season with her and she brings a lot of success to the team.â€ From Tooneâ€™s short interview, it appears as though sheâ€™s got no inkling of Earps edging for a move away from which will be huge news for the Red Devils as they get set to embark on their first ever Champions League season. Thank you for taking the time to read this article. Do remember to come back and check website for all your up-to-date local and international news stories and remember, you can also follow us on and .

newsArray.title: Kouta suggests midfield move for Curnow; Peter Daicos says Nick might have played an elimination final
creator: Peter Ryan
newsArray.description: Carlton premiership hero Anthony Koutoufides would love to see the Blues unleash dual Coleman medallist Charlie Curnow in the midfield during the finals, as tickets to the Blues-Swans elimination final sold out in just hours.
newsArray.content: In todayâ€™s AFL Briefing, your daily wrap of footy news Collingwood legend Peter Daicos doesnâ€™t expect the huge gap between games to be an issue for his son Nick when he returns for the Magpiesâ€™ second final. Nathan Jones says the 2023 Demons are motivated to add a missing piece of the puzzle by holding the premiership cup at the MCG in front of long-suffering fans. Anthony Koutoufides says the Blues should consider unleashing Charlie Curnow in the midfield. Koutoufides says Blues should consider midfield move for Curnow Peter Ryan Carlton premiership hero Anthony Koutoufides would love to see the Blues unleash dual Coleman medallist Charlie Curnow in the midfield during the finals series as they attempt to win the premiership from fifth spot. Carlton star Charlie Curnow. Credit: AFL Photos Koutoufides transformed the role of an AFL midfielder when he dominated the 1995 finals series, helping the Blues to their most recent premiership. He was the best player in the game for a period, with opponents unable to curb his rare combination of power and speed. He said he sees the same traits in Curnow and believes the Coleman medallist would strike fear into the opposition if he was swung into the midfield. â€œI would love to see him play in the midfield to see what he could do. If he could run around the wing or the midfield there would be no one in the competition that would be able to keep up with him,â€ Koutoufides said. â€œThen of course if you throw in his high marking and the capability of running forward also. â€œHe is one of those scary propositions that if you were to unleash him come finals time â€¦ he would be scary running around the football field.â€ Curnow sealed his second consecutive Coleman Medal on Sunday when he kicked two goals in the first quarter against the Giants and finished the home-and-away season on 78 goals, 14 more than the previous season when he played one less game. Next Friday night against Sydney he will play his 50th consecutive game after missing nearly two years with a knee injury. â€œI still believe heâ€™s got another level or two to go,â€ Koutoufides said. The former Carlton champion said the race for the flag was open and that the Blues had enough talent to scare the other teams in the finals. The Bluesâ€™ elimination final against the Swans sold out just hours after tickets went on sale on Wednesday. Tickets for the match, which will be played at the MCG, first went on sale at 10am on Wednesday. The AFL announced the match was sold out just after 4pm the same day. â€œShould further tickets become available as a result of unused allocations, they will be released via Ticketek on Wednesday, September 6 at 11am,â€ the AFL said. Long lay-off no worries for Nick Daicos Peter Ryan Collingwood legend Peter Daicos doesnâ€™t expect the huge gap between games to be an issue for his son Nick when he returns for the Magpiesâ€™ second final. Nick Daicos was ruled out for more than a month when he suffered a hairline fracture in his right knee early in August. Nick Daicos wonâ€™t have played since round 21 when he returns for finals Credit: AFL Photos Peter Daicos said he did not expect Nick to play in the qualifying final against Melbourne despite coach Craig McRae keeping the door slightly ajar for an earlier-than expected return. The club had been firm that he would not be available in the first week of the finals, but McRae told Fox Footy on Tuesday night he preferred not to rule the slim possibility out completely. The senior Daicos was confident that Nick would not be hampered by time out of the game when he does make his return, saying Nick had slotted in fine at the start of his AFL career, despite having played very few games in the preceding years due to COVID-19. â€œOne of his good attributes or skill sets is his hard running and if they came off a little bit heâ€™s still going to be up there,â€ Daicos said. He said he sometimes cringes when he sees what is said or written about his son because he knows he would, ideally, prefer to work away in the background. â€œI ask him at times how he is feeling with it and I know him pretty well, so he tells me as it is. He is pretty comfortable with it and he uses a lot of that with self motivation as well,â€ Daicos said. Peter said the thinking around Nickâ€™s selection may have been different if Collingwood didnâ€™t have a double chance. â€œHad it been an elimination [final] there would have been a lot more thinking going into rolling the dice. There is a bigger scalp to be had here and we have to try to get our players to the end of the season, so itâ€™s a management thing.â€ He said McRae would have been keeping his sonâ€™s spirits up as he worked his way through the rehabilitation program. â€œHeâ€™s doing the work and he is keen to get back.â€ The Magpies finished on top of the ladder but will go in to the qualifying final as only slight favourites against the Demons, with Daicos saying the premiership race is wide open. He praised the efforts of his other son, Josh, who has been a key player on the wing in 2023. He was one of 40 players nominated for the All-Australian team. Loading â€œIâ€™m pleased for Josh because of the amount of work [he has done],â€ Daicos said. â€œOne of the other things that is coming through now with his maturity is his leadership. He is just growing in that part of his game.â€ Peter kicked 97 goals in the Magpiesâ€™ breakthrough 1990 premiership-winning season and is a member of the Australian Football Hall of Fame. He said missing games wonâ€™t help Nickâ€™s Brownlow chances, but it was hard to predict who would poll votes anyway. MCG premiership motivating Melbourne: Jones Peter Ryan Melbourne great Nathan Jones says the 2023 Demons are motivated to add a missing piece of the puzzle by holding the premiership cup at the MCG in front of long-suffering fans. The Demons won their drought-breaking premiership at Optus Stadium in Perth with most of their diehard fans forced to watch the win on television while stuck in a COVID-19 lockdown in Melbourne. The Demons want to hold a cup up at the MCG Credit: Getty Images Jones, who played a key role in lifting the club from the doldrums to become premiers, said there â€œwas absolutely no doubtâ€ his former teammates wanted to fill that gap this season. â€œThat has been the motivating factor,â€ Jones said. â€œIt was the only real thing missing from 2021, the fact that Melbourne was in COVID lockdown and none of our supporters could get across there [to Perth]. â€œThey are absolutely driven to get back to being part of a grand final game again at the MCG and being able to hold up the cup officially in front of all our diehard fans that have been through so much for such a long period of time, for 50-plus years.â€ Jones said it was devastating to watch Jake Melksham hurt his knee in the final round, denying him a chance to play in a potential flag after he watched the 2021 game from the sidelines. He said he would still play a role in September but clearly his future was up in the air after he was diagnosed with an ACL rupture. Melkshamâ€™s absence has created a gap inside 50 at the Demons. Jones said he would select premiership forward Tom McDonald over makeshift forward Brodie Grundy, although he admitted it was a tough decision for the match committee. â€œHeâ€™s proved in that forward role, in particular,â€ Jones said. â€œI also think the way Max [Gawn] plays his best footy is spending a large chunk of time as the key ruckman and pinch hitting down [forward] for small periods of time.â€ Jones is optimistic about the Demonsâ€™ chances, saying they are timing their run well this season as they build towards their best form. newsArray.title: BBC Sport: Everton make approach to sign Brighton player after Â£23m+ development
creator: George Overhill
newsArray.description: Everton are â€œkeenâ€ on signing Steven Alzate from Brighton and have already been in touch over a move, according to BBC Sport. Simon Stone reported via Twitter Wednesday (30 August) that the Colombian international â€œwill be allowed to leaveâ€ after the Seagulls brought in Carlos Baleba, with Wolves, Sevilla and Fiorentina also interested. In an ... The post BBC Sport: Everton make approach to sign Brighton player after Â£23m+ development appeared first on Goodison News.
newsArray.content: Simon Stone reported via Wednesday (30 August) that the Colombian international â€œwill be allowed to leaveâ€ after the Seagulls brought in Carlos Baleba, with Wolves, Sevilla and Fiorentina also interested. In an update on the BBC Sport website Stone added that following the Â£23.2million deal for Baleba both the Toffees and Wolves have already made approaches to Brighton for Alzate, 24, but the Serie A and La Liga options would also come with European football. Everton are before the window shuts after completing a move for Â£25.7m striker Beto from Udinese. Central midfield doesnâ€™t appear to be an obvious priority based on the current state of Sean Dycheâ€™s squad but Tom Davies has left this summer and there is always the threat of late developments around Amadou Onana on deadline day. Alex Iwobi has emerged as potential departure following long delays over the Nigerian internationalâ€™s new contract at Goodison Park, and Dyche was thought to still want wide options as it is with Demarai Gray also . Alzate had already fallen down the pecking order at Brighton prior to this summer, having just returned from a loan in Belgium with Standard Liege, and the mega-money sale of Moises Caicedo to Chelsea hasnâ€™t opened the door for more football at the Amex for him. It has been an absolute slog once more during the window but Dyche has seen his squad boosted by five arrivals, with all but one coming in attacking areas. However, he has experienced injury crises in multiple positions during his time on Merseyside already so is clearly minded to pick up cheap reinforcements where they are available. If Alzate is looking to add to his 43 Premier League appearances then Wolvesâ€™ own financial pressures should prevent them from easily beating the Toffees to this deal, although the overseas options might win the day. His versatility could be a useful option for Dyche later in the season and it sounds like a late push is now in progress.

newsArray.title: Christian Dailly: Cafu, chronic pain and quantum physics with the Dundee United hero who always â€˜felt differentâ€™
creator: Alan Temple
newsArray.description: Dailly reflected on his playing career, and new endeavours, with Courier Sport.
newsArray.content: Christian Dailly was ready to sign the contract. Another two years under the watchful eye of Dundee United icon Paul Sturrock at Southend United. Dailly would be 41 years of age by the time that deal expired but, as a health fanatic enjoying a splendid autumn to his career, there was little doubt that he possessed the longevity. â€œI was fit and playing well,â€ Dailly told . â€œBut I was really into my studies and it was difficult to balance everything â€” my head was in the literature and it felt like a jigsaw I wanted to devote myself to putting together. â€œI said to and the chairman, â€œIâ€™ve actually changed my mind on the way down. Iâ€™m not going to sign the contract,â€ and I retired on the spot!â€ Dailly had become completely engrossed in a sports science degree. He had undertaken the first two years while still playing, and was determined to give the final three years his undivided attention. This was no mere Plan B; break glass in case of failure to become a coach or pundit. He had found a calling. In the years since his retirement, Dailly has leapt headlong into cutting-edge research on aerobic fitness, strength and nutrition. coached athletics for a time, even working with Team GB representatives. He sought to educate on the dangers of â€œno pain, no gainâ€ overtraining. He now works with the general public after creating Zone 1 Health. â€œWe have seen people go into diabetes remission, go from having chronic pain to being pain-free,â€ Dailly continues. â€œWeâ€™ve got a guy who recently did his second . Before that, he had two heart attacks and was scared to do any exercise. â€œI have the same passion as I ever did working with athletes, so donâ€™t miss that side of it.â€ Dailly is likely to be the only interviewee to discuss research on Neanderthal heel-bones and their relevance to long-distance running. Or how the human body is akin to self-regulating complex weather systems. Or to profess an interest in quantum physics. â€œI like to find out how things function,â€ he smiles. â€œItâ€™s good fun. â€œItâ€™s a bit unusual to have quantum physics books by your bed before football matches, like I did. People are looking at you saying, â€œreally?â€ But I enjoyed them.â€ Not the footballing archetype, certainly. â€œI definitely felt different,â€ continued Dailly. â€œNot better or worse. I just felt like I was always looking after myself. It definitely made me a little but more isolated â€” but I was okay with that. That was who I was. â€œEveryone was alright with me but you had all the players â€” all these different interactions and relationships â€” and I was But thatâ€™s maybe why I could captain teams.â€ He added: â€œI was too young to captain , if Iâ€™m honest. But I went on to captain every team I played for, so maybe there is something about being â€œover thereâ€ that allowed me to speak and act freely.â€ Daillyâ€™s curiosity has always been present. But it did not extend to questioning his peers as he emerged through the youth ranks at Dundee United as a fresh-faced 16-year-old. â€œI was inherently good and would think, â€œthis person is my boss so he will definitely know the right thing to doâ€,â€ recalled Dailly, who scored in each of his first three games for the club while, in his words, â€œstill playing on instinctâ€. â€œWith a scientific mind, I would go back and question everything I was told.â€ . He scored 21 goals, lifted the 1994 Scottish Cup, was relegated, made captain, unmade captain, promoted and sold to Derby County for Â£1million. Eventful. By the time he departed for Pride Park, Dailly was a fine centre-back. He would represent Scotland 67 times, play at the 1998 World Cup, win five major honours and reach the Uefa Cup final with Rangers in 2008. But he still wonders how his career may have panned out if he had remained that waspish, instinctive striker who closed down Ally Maxwell at Hampden Park, admitting he felt â€œover-coachedâ€ with â€œThere are parts of me that ended up better, but when I just played,â€ he continued. â€œThere is a different world where I stayed that striker. I think I was over-coached, albeit with the best of intentions. I took everything as rules.â€ And he would love to see emerging youngsters emboldened to retain their natural flair and problem-solving ability. â€œOne thing I learned about coaching â€” and I took this on board myself â€” is not to coach rules,â€ he continued. â€œI think of strikers I played with during my career. Guys like Ally McCoist, and Kris Boyd all did what they wanted. They ran where they thought the ball was going! They didnâ€™t follow rules; their game was a natural evolution. â€œOne of the biggest problems in sport, generally, is that coaches can be far too prescriptive and ruin people. Telling people there is a â€œcorrectâ€ running style, or a way to play football, or an amount of touches you should take. â€œYouâ€™ve got to let people figure things out.â€ At this point, Dailly reserves a special mention for his former Scotland manager â€œ for that,â€ added Dailly. â€œIt didnâ€™t matter if you were playing against Cafu â€” heâ€™d say, â€œyouâ€™re better than him, run him all day and show him!â€ â€œHe was telling me that from the age of 14, when he was my manager with Scotland schoolboys. Schoolboy games? The World Cup? â€œJust you run, Christianâ€. It was so much fun. Pure freedom.â€ Chatting to in a suite at Hampden Park, scene of THAT triumph in 1994, Dailly appears genuinely taken aback when reminded that 2024 will mark 30 years since Time flies, and all that. Daillyâ€™s tireless harrying of Maxwell created the sparking wild celebrations among the Arabs as their interminable wait to lift the famous old trophy ended. â€œThe memory is so vivid to me,â€ Dailly adds. â€œI can still remember making the decision to close down Ally Maxwell and that vision of my shot trickling across the goal-line and bouncing off the post; that panic, thinking, â€œitâ€™s not going to go in.â€ â€œSeeing Brewster come in and all the fans in the corner going mad was amazing. It was so special to take the trophy back to Dundee after all those years. It was a great time, and really well deserved.â€ He smiled: â€œIâ€™ve actually watched that game back a couple of times. I donâ€™t generally watch many games back â€” I should have done that more in my career; I should have analysed and learned â€” but Iâ€™ve made an exception for that one!â€

newsArray.content: Der letzte Tag der Transferphase rÃ¼ckt immer nÃ¤her. Ex-Bayern-Manager und Insider Michael Reschke erwartet einige Ãœberraschungen. MÃ¼nchen â€“ Der Countdown lÃ¤uft. . Bis dahin haben die Vereine die MÃ¶glichkeit, Spieler zu verpflichten und abzugeben. Der sogenannte Deadline Day ist ein Spektakel fÃ¼r FuÃŸball-Fans, das Transferfinale ist aber gleichzeitig auch eine hektische Phase fÃ¼r Vereine und Berater. Michael Reschke (65) kennt beide Seiten des GeschÃ¤fts. Er war jahrelang als Bundesliga-Manager (Leverkusen, , Stuttgart, Schalke) mittendrin und ist aktuell auch als Head of European Football der mÃ¤chtigen Berater-Agentur CAA Stellar involviert. Das tz-Interview. FC Bayern: Was passiert am Deadline-Day? Dieser Tag birgt Brisanz fÃ¼r alle, die involviert sind. Berater, Club-Manager, SekretÃ¤rinnen, Trainer, die Medien-Verantwortlichen und natÃ¼rlich allen voran die betroffenen Spieler - alle sind auf Hab-Acht-Stellung. Es herrscht viel Hektik und Spannung. Man muss extrem aufmerksam sein, damit keine Fehler passieren: bei Vertragswerken, den Zahlen, der Umsetzung von AlternativlÃ¶sungen, da sind viele Themen zu bedenken. Trainer, CEO, Sportvorstand, Finanzvorstand und die Scoutingabteilung sind permanent im Austausch. Es geht um sehr wichtige sportliche und wirtschaftliche Entscheidungen. So ist es - und zwar fÃ¼r alle Beteiligten. Es gilt zahlreiche Faktoren zu berÃ¼cksichtigen. Man muss schnell reagieren und der Entscheidungsdruck kann dabei sehr hoch werden. Wenn ein wirtschaftlich extrem interessantes Angebot fÃ¼r einen transferwilligen Spieler reinkommt, dann muss man innerhalb kÃ¼rzester Zeit sinnvolle AlternativlÃ¶sungen umsetzen kÃ¶nnen. Und im Idealfall mit der Alternativ-WunschlÃ¶sung, seinem Berater und seinem bisherigen Verein schon VorgesprÃ¤che gefÃ¼hrt haben oder zumindest ein VertrauensverhÃ¤ltnis besitzen, dass Verhandlungen zielfÃ¼hrend schnell ablaufen kÃ¶nnen. Der Deadline Day ist schon eine Achterbahnfahrt, die auÃŸergewÃ¶hnliches Format hat. Ist ja auch schon mal passiert, dass ein Fax zwei Minuten zu spÃ¤t kamâ€¦ Aber so was von! Meistens schlieÃŸt das Transferfenster um 18 Uhr. Bis dahin muss der GroÃŸteil der Dokumente bei der Liga eingereicht sein. Und es gibt Risiken: Bei einem Last-Minute-Wechsel kann der Medizin-Check meist erst nachtrÃ¤glich stattfinden. Und wenn dabei wider Erwarten ein Problem analysiert wird, kann man den Transfer trotzdem nicht rÃ¼ckgÃ¤ngig machen. Das verbieten die Regularien. Es ist eine Frage des Naturells und der Erfahrung, wie man solche Situationen und den Tag managt. FC Bayern: â€Was tut sich bei den MÃ¼nchnern im Mittelfeld? Bleibt Gravenberch oder nicht?â€œ Die sind sehr intensiv und lang. Permanent kann es extreme VerÃ¤nderungen auf dem Markt geben. Verletzungen, unerwartete VerkÃ¤ufe oder weil man eine bedeutsame KaderlÃ¼cke noch nicht schlieÃŸen konnte. Und das Zeitfenster, in dem man agieren kann, wird immer kleiner. Anspannung und Entscheidungsdruck wachsen. TÃ¤glich werden neue Szenarien durchgespielt. Durch eine hohe Transfereinnahme ist beispielsweise der Transfer eines Spielers mÃ¶glich, den man schon vorher verpflichten wollte, aber aus wirtschaftlichen GrÃ¼nden nicht konnte. Dieser Spieler ist aber vielleicht grade kurz vor dem Vertragsabschluss mit einem anderen Club. Es kann zugehen wie in einem aufgeregten Taubenschlag. Solch ein Transfer-Finale fordert permanentes Umdenken. Nehmen wir die Bayern als Beispiel. . Was tut sich bei den MÃ¼nchnern im Mittelfeld? Bleibt Gravenberch oder nicht? Wenn er wechselt: Per Leihe oder Verkauf? Nutzt man daraus resultierende Einnahmen und die Gehaltsersparnis, um vielleicht den Tuchel-Wunsch nach einer zusÃ¤tzlichen Sechs zu erfÃ¼llen? Was bedeutet dies fÃ¼r Kimmich, Goretzka und Laimer und fÃ¼r die gesamte Balance im Kader? Wenn man mÃ¶gliche Transfereinnahmen und Gehaltsersparnisse fÃ¼r beide zusammenrechnet, dÃ¼rfte ein Gesamtvolumen von Ã¼ber 80 Millionen Euro zusammenkommen. FC Bayern: â€Geld ist vorhanden und der Positionsbedarf ist groÃŸâ€œ Es wÃ¤re dann jedem klar: Geld ist vorhanden und der Positionsbedarf ist groÃŸ. Dadurch werden mÃ¶gliche AblÃ¶sen nicht geringer. GrundsÃ¤tzlich sind die Bayern aber in einer starken Position und werden kein Geschenkpaket schnÃ¼ren und nur verkaufen, wenn man interessante Alternativen umsetzen kann und zudem wirtschaftlich oder sportlich profitiert. Dreesen, HoeneÃŸ, Rummenigge und Neppe sind erfahrene Dealmaker und kennen das GeschÃ¤ft aus dem Effeff. Sicher ist eines, die KÃ¶pfe werden rauchen und natÃ¼rlich hat auch Thomas Tuchel klare Vorstellungen. Ich glaube, dass noch Unvorhergesehenes passiert, es wirtschaftliche Megadeals und mÃ¤chtig Bewegung geben wird. Bei den Saudis geht die Transferperiode noch weitere drei Wochen und das kann fÃ¼r mÃ¤chtig Unruhe sorgen. Sollte ein saudi-arabischer Verein noch an einem europÃ¤ischen Topstar interessiert sein und bereit sein, extrem zu investieren, wird es speziell. Bis zum 1. September kÃ¶nnte der abgebende Club zumindest noch reagieren, danach geht dies nicht mehr und Topclubs werden keinen wichtigen Profi mehr ziehen lassen. newsArray.title: â€˜One Of The Bestâ€™ â€“ Manchester United Star Pleads For Teammate To Stay
creator: Aaron Hindhaugh
newsArray.description: Manchester Unitedâ€™s Ella Toone has spoken to Sky Sports about how she hopes to see Mary Earps stay amid interest from other clubs around Europe. Earps has risen to stardom over the past couple of years and she largely has Sarina Wiegman to thank for that because prior to her arrival as the England manager, [â€¦]
newsArray.content: Earps has risen to stardom over the past couple of years and she largely has Sarina Wiegman to thank for that because prior to her arrival as the England manager, it was Ellie Roebuck who was the regular number one for the Lionesses and seen as the future to stopper for years to come. However, an injury to Roebuck and a huge amount of faith from Wiegman later and Earps is now widely regarded as the best goalkeeper in Womenâ€™s football and even has the trophy to prove it having been voted the best between the sticks earlier this year. Most Read on Euro Weekly News Ella Toone hopeful of Mary Earps staying at Man United While starring for England and in the Womenâ€™s Super League, it has certainly been over the last two summer tournaments in which Earps has spent the show and proven to the world just how good she is with the ball at her feet and also keeping it out of her net. Therefore, itâ€™s no surprise that an unnamed Champions League club lodged a world record bid for Earps earlier in the transfer window, just a few days after England had experienced World Cup heartache out in Australia at the hands of Spain, making it the second record bid have received this year following bid for Alessia Russo. "She's been unbelievable" Ella Toone has her fingers crossed that Mary Earps will be staying at Manchester United! ğŸ¤ğŸ”´ â€” Sky Sports WSL (@SkySportsWSL) rejected the bid out of hand and that unnamed side are yet to return with an improved offer for Earps, and her teammate, Ella Toone, is hopeful that the impressive shot-stopper will remain in Manchester. She said: â€œSheâ€™s one of the best, sheâ€™s been unbelievable in the past two tournaments for England and sheâ€™s had an unbelievable season for [Man] United. Eaprs is set to attract further attention â€œSo, sheâ€™s going to have interest in her, sheâ€™s one of the best keepers in the world at the moment. â€œIâ€™m glad weâ€™re hopefully getting to keep her and hopefully we have a successful season with her and she brings a lot of success to the team.â€ From Tooneâ€™s short interview, it appears as though sheâ€™s got no inkling of Earps edging for a move away from which will be huge news for the Red Devils as they get set to embark on their first ever Champions League season. Thank you for taking the time to read this article. Do remember to come back and check website for all your up-to-date local and international news stories and remember, you can also follow us on and .

newsArray.title: Kouta suggests midfield move for Curnow; Peter Daicos says Nick might have played an elimination final
creator: Peter Ryan
newsArray.description: Carlton premiership hero Anthony Koutoufides would love to see the Blues unleash dual Coleman medallist Charlie Curnow in the midfield during the finals, as tickets to the Blues-Swans elimination final sold out in just hours.
newsArray.content: In todayâ€™s AFL Briefing, your daily wrap of footy news Collingwood legend Peter Daicos doesnâ€™t expect the huge gap between games to be an issue for his son Nick when he returns for the Magpiesâ€™ second final. Nathan Jones says the 2023 Demons are motivated to add a missing piece of the puzzle by holding the premiership cup at the MCG in front of long-suffering fans. Anthony Koutoufides says the Blues should consider unleashing Charlie Curnow in the midfield. Koutoufides says Blues should consider midfield move for Curnow Peter Ryan Carlton premiership hero Anthony Koutoufides would love to see the Blues unleash dual Coleman medallist Charlie Curnow in the midfield during the finals series as they attempt to win the premiership from fifth spot. Carlton star Charlie Curnow. Credit: AFL Photos Koutoufides transformed the role of an AFL midfielder when he dominated the 1995 finals series, helping the Blues to their most recent premiership. He was the best player in the game for a period, with opponents unable to curb his rare combination of power and speed. He said he sees the same traits in Curnow and believes the Coleman medallist would strike fear into the opposition if he was swung into the midfield. â€œI would love to see him play in the midfield to see what he could do. If he could run around the wing or the midfield there would be no one in the competition that would be able to keep up with him,â€ Koutoufides said. â€œThen of course if you throw in his high marking and the capability of running forward also. â€œHe is one of those scary propositions that if you were to unleash him come finals time â€¦ he would be scary running around the football field.â€ Curnow sealed his second consecutive Coleman Medal on Sunday when he kicked two goals in the first quarter against the Giants and finished the home-and-away season on 78 goals, 14 more than the previous season when he played one less game. Next Friday night against Sydney he will play his 50th consecutive game after missing nearly two years with a knee injury. â€œI still believe heâ€™s got another level or two to go,â€ Koutoufides said. The former Carlton champion said the race for the flag was open and that the Blues had enough talent to scare the other teams in the finals. The Bluesâ€™ elimination final against the Swans sold out just hours after tickets went on sale on Wednesday. Tickets for the match, which will be played at the MCG, first went on sale at 10am on Wednesday. The AFL announced the match was sold out just after 4pm the same day. â€œShould further tickets become available as a result of unused allocations, they will be released via Ticketek on Wednesday, September 6 at 11am,â€ the AFL said. Long lay-off no worries for Nick Daicos Peter Ryan Collingwood legend Peter Daicos doesnâ€™t expect the huge gap between games to be an issue for his son Nick when he returns for the Magpiesâ€™ second final. Nick Daicos was ruled out for more than a month when he suffered a hairline fracture in his right knee early in August. Nick Daicos wonâ€™t have played since round 21 when he returns for finals Credit: AFL Photos Peter Daicos said he did not expect Nick to play in the qualifying final against Melbourne despite coach Craig McRae keeping the door slightly ajar for an earlier-than expected return. The club had been firm that he would not be available in the first week of the finals, but McRae told Fox Footy on Tuesday night he preferred not to rule the slim possibility out completely. The senior Daicos was confident that Nick would not be hampered by time out of the game when he does make his return, saying Nick had slotted in fine at the start of his AFL career, despite having played very few games in the preceding years due to COVID-19. â€œOne of his good attributes or skill sets is his hard running and if they came off a little bit heâ€™s still going to be up there,â€ Daicos said. He said he sometimes cringes when he sees what is said or written about his son because he knows he would, ideally, prefer to work away in the background. â€œI ask him at times how he is feeling with it and I know him pretty well, so he tells me as it is. He is pretty comfortable with it and he uses a lot of that with self motivation as well,â€ Daicos said. Peter said the thinking around Nickâ€™s selection may have been different if Collingwood didnâ€™t have a double chance. â€œHad it been an elimination [final] there would have been a lot more thinking going into rolling the dice. There is a bigger scalp to be had here and we have to try to get our players to the end of the season, so itâ€™s a management thing.â€ He said McRae would have been keeping his sonâ€™s spirits up as he worked his way through the rehabilitation program. â€œHeâ€™s doing the work and he is keen to get back.â€ The Magpies finished on top of the ladder but will go in to the qualifying final as only slight favourites against the Demons, with Daicos saying the premiership race is wide open. He praised the efforts of his other son, Josh, who has been a key player on the wing in 2023. He was one of 40 players nominated for the All-Australian team. Loading â€œIâ€™m pleased for Josh because of the amount of work [he has done],â€ Daicos said. â€œOne of the other things that is coming through now with his maturity is his leadership. He is just growing in that part of his game.â€ Peter kicked 97 goals in the Magpiesâ€™ breakthrough 1990 premiership-winning season and is a member of the Australian Football Hall of Fame. He said missing games wonâ€™t help Nickâ€™s Brownlow chances, but it was hard to predict who would poll votes anyway. MCG premiership motivating Melbourne: Jones Peter Ryan Melbourne great Nathan Jones says the 2023 Demons are motivated to add a missing piece of the puzzle by holding the premiership cup at the MCG in front of long-suffering fans. The Demons won their drought-breaking premiership at Optus Stadium in Perth with most of their diehard fans forced to watch the win on television while stuck in a COVID-19 lockdown in Melbourne. The Demons want to hold a cup up at the MCG Credit: Getty Images Jones, who played a key role in lifting the club from the doldrums to become premiers, said there â€œwas absolutely no doubtâ€ his former teammates wanted to fill that gap this season. â€œThat has been the motivating factor,â€ Jones said. â€œIt was the only real thing missing from 2021, the fact that Melbourne was in COVID lockdown and none of our supporters could get across there [to Perth]. â€œThey are absolutely driven to get back to being part of a grand final game again at the MCG and being able to hold up the cup officially in front of all our diehard fans that have been through so much for such a long period of time, for 50-plus years.â€ Jones said it was devastating to watch Jake Melksham hurt his knee in the final round, denying him a chance to play in a potential flag after he watched the 2021 game from the sidelines. He said he would still play a role in September but clearly his future was up in the air after he was diagnosed with an ACL rupture. Melkshamâ€™s absence has created a gap inside 50 at the Demons. Jones said he would select premiership forward Tom McDonald over makeshift forward Brodie Grundy, although he admitted it was a tough decision for the match committee. â€œHeâ€™s proved in that forward role, in particular,â€ Jones said. â€œI also think the way Max [Gawn] plays his best footy is spending a large chunk of time as the key ruckman and pinch hitting down [forward] for small periods of time.â€ Jones is optimistic about the Demonsâ€™ chances, saying they are timing their run well this season as they build towards their best form. newsArray.title: BBC Sport: Everton make approach to sign Brighton player after Â£23m+ development
creator: George Overhill
newsArray.description: Everton are â€œkeenâ€ on signing Steven Alzate from Brighton and have already been in touch over a move, according to BBC Sport. Simon Stone reported via Twitter Wednesday (30 August) that the Colombian international â€œwill be allowed to leaveâ€ after the Seagulls brought in Carlos Baleba, with Wolves, Sevilla and Fiorentina also interested. In an ... The post BBC Sport: Everton make approach to sign Brighton player after Â£23m+ development appeared first on Goodison News.
newsArray.content: Simon Stone reported via Wednesday (30 August) that the Colombian international â€œwill be allowed to leaveâ€ after the Seagulls brought in Carlos Baleba, with Wolves, Sevilla and Fiorentina also interested. In an update on the BBC Sport website Stone added that following the Â£23.2million deal for Baleba both the Toffees and Wolves have already made approaches to Brighton for Alzate, 24, but the Serie A and La Liga options would also come with European football. Everton are before the window shuts after completing a move for Â£25.7m striker Beto from Udinese. Central midfield doesnâ€™t appear to be an obvious priority based on the current state of Sean Dycheâ€™s squad but Tom Davies has left this summer and there is always the threat of late developments around Amadou Onana on deadline day. Alex Iwobi has emerged as potential departure following long delays over the Nigerian internationalâ€™s new contract at Goodison Park, and Dyche was thought to still want wide options as it is with Demarai Gray also . Alzate had already fallen down the pecking order at Brighton prior to this summer, having just returned from a loan in Belgium with Standard Liege, and the mega-money sale of Moises Caicedo to Chelsea hasnâ€™t opened the door for more football at the Amex for him. It has been an absolute slog once more during the window but Dyche has seen his squad boosted by five arrivals, with all but one coming in attacking areas. However, he has experienced injury crises in multiple positions during his time on Merseyside already so is clearly minded to pick up cheap reinforcements where they are available. If Alzate is looking to add to his 43 Premier League appearances then Wolvesâ€™ own financial pressures should prevent them from easily beating the Toffees to this deal, although the overseas options might win the day. His versatility could be a useful option for Dyche later in the season and it sounds like a late push is now in progress.

newsArray.title: Christian Dailly: Cafu, chronic pain and quantum physics with the Dundee United hero who always â€˜felt differentâ€™
creator: Alan Temple
newsArray.description: Dailly reflected on his playing career, and new endeavours, with Courier Sport.
newsArray.content: Christian Dailly was ready to sign the contract. Another two years under the watchful eye of Dundee United icon Paul Sturrock at Southend United. Dailly would be 41 years of age by the time that deal expired but, as a health fanatic enjoying a splendid autumn to his career, there was little doubt that he possessed the longevity. â€œI was fit and playing well,â€ Dailly told . â€œBut I was really into my studies and it was difficult to balance everything â€” my head was in the literature and it felt like a jigsaw I wanted to devote myself to putting together. â€œI said to and the chairman, â€œIâ€™ve actually changed my mind on the way down. Iâ€™m not going to sign the contract,â€ and I retired on the spot!â€ Dailly had become completely engrossed in a sports science degree. He had undertaken the first two years while still playing, and was determined to give the final three years his undivided attention. This was no mere Plan B; break glass in case of failure to become a coach or pundit. He had found a calling. In the years since his retirement, Dailly has leapt headlong into cutting-edge research on aerobic fitness, strength and nutrition. coached athletics for a time, even working with Team GB representatives. He sought to educate on the dangers of â€œno pain, no gainâ€ overtraining. He now works with the general public after creating Zone 1 Health. â€œWe have seen people go into diabetes remission, go from having chronic pain to being pain-free,â€ Dailly continues. â€œWeâ€™ve got a guy who recently did his second . Before that, he had two heart attacks and was scared to do any exercise. â€œI have the same passion as I ever did working with athletes, so donâ€™t miss that side of it.â€ Dailly is likely to be the only interviewee to discuss research on Neanderthal heel-bones and their relevance to long-distance running. Or how the human body is akin to self-regulating complex weather systems. Or to profess an interest in quantum physics. â€œI like to find out how things function,â€ he smiles. â€œItâ€™s good fun. â€œItâ€™s a bit unusual to have quantum physics books by your bed before football matches, like I did. People are looking at you saying, â€œreally?â€ But I enjoyed them.â€ Not the footballing archetype, certainly. â€œI definitely felt different,â€ continued Dailly. â€œNot better or worse. I just felt like I was always looking after myself. It definitely made me a little but more isolated â€” but I was okay with that. That was who I was. â€œEveryone was alright with me but you had all the players â€” all these different interactions and relationships â€” and I was But thatâ€™s maybe why I could captain teams.â€ He added: â€œI was too young to captain , if Iâ€™m honest. But I went on to captain every team I played for, so maybe there is something about being â€œover thereâ€ that allowed me to speak and act freely.â€ Daillyâ€™s curiosity has always been present. But it did not extend to questioning his peers as he emerged through the youth ranks at Dundee United as a fresh-faced 16-year-old. â€œI was inherently good and would think, â€œthis person is my boss so he will definitely know the right thing to doâ€,â€ recalled Dailly, who scored in each of his first three games for the club while, in his words, â€œstill playing on instinctâ€. â€œWith a scientific mind, I would go back and question everything I was told.â€ . He scored 21 goals, lifted the 1994 Scottish Cup, was relegated, made captain, unmade captain, promoted and sold to Derby County for Â£1million. Eventful. By the time he departed for Pride Park, Dailly was a fine centre-back. He would represent Scotland 67 times, play at the 1998 World Cup, win five major honours and reach the Uefa Cup final with Rangers in 2008. But he still wonders how his career may have panned out if he had remained that waspish, instinctive striker who closed down Ally Maxwell at Hampden Park, admitting he felt â€œover-coachedâ€ with â€œThere are parts of me that ended up better, but when I just played,â€ he continued. â€œThere is a different world where I stayed that striker. I think I was over-coached, albeit with the best of intentions. I took everything as rules.â€ And he would love to see emerging youngsters emboldened to retain their natural flair and problem-solving ability. â€œOne thing I learned about coaching â€” and I took this on board myself â€” is not to coach rules,â€ he continued. â€œI think of strikers I played with during my career. Guys like Ally McCoist, and Kris Boyd all did what they wanted. They ran where they thought the ball was going! They didnâ€™t follow rules; their game was a natural evolution. â€œOne of the biggest problems in sport, generally, is that coaches can be far too prescriptive and ruin people. Telling people there is a â€œcorrectâ€ running style, or a way to play football, or an amount of touches you should take. â€œYouâ€™ve got to let people figure things out.â€ At this point, Dailly reserves a special mention for his former Scotland manager â€œ for that,â€ added Dailly. â€œIt didnâ€™t matter if you were playing against Cafu â€” heâ€™d say, â€œyouâ€™re better than him, run him all day and show him!â€ â€œHe was telling me that from the age of 14, when he was my manager with Scotland schoolboys. Schoolboy games? The World Cup? â€œJust you run, Christianâ€. It was so much fun. Pure freedom.â€ Chatting to in a suite at Hampden Park, scene of THAT triumph in 1994, Dailly appears genuinely taken aback when reminded that 2024 will mark 30 years since Time flies, and all that. Daillyâ€™s tireless harrying of Maxwell created the sparking wild celebrations among the Arabs as their interminable wait to lift the famous old trophy ended. â€œThe memory is so vivid to me,â€ Dailly adds. â€œI can still remember making the decision to close down Ally Maxwell and that vision of my shot trickling across the goal-line and bouncing off the post; that panic, thinking, â€œitâ€™s not going to go in.â€ â€œSeeing Brewster come in and all the fans in the corner going mad was amazing. It was so special to take the trophy back to Dundee after all those years. It was a great time, and really well deserved.â€ He smiled: â€œIâ€™ve actually watched that game back a couple of times. I donâ€™t generally watch many games back â€” I should have done that more in my career; I should have analysed and learned â€” but Iâ€™ve made an exception for that one!â€

newsArray.content: Der letzte Tag der Transferphase rÃ¼ckt immer nÃ¤her. Ex-Bayern-Manager und Insider Michael Reschke erwartet einige Ãœberraschungen. MÃ¼nchen â€“ Der Countdown lÃ¤uft. . Bis dahin haben die Vereine die MÃ¶glichkeit, Spieler zu verpflichten und abzugeben. Der sogenannte Deadline Day ist ein Spektakel fÃ¼r FuÃŸball-Fans, das Transferfinale ist aber gleichzeitig auch eine hektische Phase fÃ¼r Vereine und Berater. Michael Reschke (65) kennt beide Seiten des GeschÃ¤fts. Er war jahrelang als Bundesliga-Manager (Leverkusen, , Stuttgart, Schalke) mittendrin und ist aktuell auch als Head of European Football der mÃ¤chtigen Berater-Agentur CAA Stellar involviert. Das tz-Interview. FC Bayern: Was passiert am Deadline-Day? Dieser Tag birgt Brisanz fÃ¼r alle, die involviert sind. Berater, Club-Manager, SekretÃ¤rinnen, Trainer, die Medien-Verantwortlichen und natÃ¼rlich allen voran die betroffenen Spieler - alle sind auf Hab-Acht-Stellung. Es herrscht viel Hektik und Spannung. Man muss extrem aufmerksam sein, damit keine Fehler passieren: bei Vertragswerken, den Zahlen, der Umsetzung von AlternativlÃ¶sungen, da sind viele Themen zu bedenken. Trainer, CEO, Sportvorstand, Finanzvorstand und die Scoutingabteilung sind permanent im Austausch. Es geht um sehr wichtige sportliche und wirtschaftliche Entscheidungen. So ist es - und zwar fÃ¼r alle Beteiligten. Es gilt zahlreiche Faktoren zu berÃ¼cksichtigen. Man muss schnell reagieren und der Entscheidungsdruck kann dabei sehr hoch werden. Wenn ein wirtschaftlich extrem interessantes Angebot fÃ¼r einen transferwilligen Spieler reinkommt, dann muss man innerhalb kÃ¼rzester Zeit sinnvolle AlternativlÃ¶sungen umsetzen kÃ¶nnen. Und im Idealfall mit der Alternativ-WunschlÃ¶sung, seinem Berater und seinem bisherigen Verein schon VorgesprÃ¤che gefÃ¼hrt haben oder zumindest ein VertrauensverhÃ¤ltnis besitzen, dass Verhandlungen zielfÃ¼hrend schnell ablaufen kÃ¶nnen. Der Deadline Day ist schon eine Achterbahnfahrt, die auÃŸergewÃ¶hnliches Format hat. Ist ja auch schon mal passiert, dass ein Fax zwei Minuten zu spÃ¤t kamâ€¦ Aber so was von! Meistens schlieÃŸt das Transferfenster um 18 Uhr. Bis dahin muss der GroÃŸteil der Dokumente bei der Liga eingereicht sein. Und es gibt Risiken: Bei einem Last-Minute-Wechsel kann der Medizin-Check meist erst nachtrÃ¤glich stattfinden. Und wenn dabei wider Erwarten ein Problem analysiert wird, kann man den Transfer trotzdem nicht rÃ¼ckgÃ¤ngig machen. Das verbieten die Regularien. Es ist eine Frage des Naturells und der Erfahrung, wie man solche Situationen und den Tag managt. FC Bayern: â€Was tut sich bei den MÃ¼nchnern im Mittelfeld? Bleibt Gravenberch oder nicht?â€œ Die sind sehr intensiv und lang. Permanent kann es extreme VerÃ¤nderungen auf dem Markt geben. Verletzungen, unerwartete VerkÃ¤ufe oder weil man eine bedeutsame KaderlÃ¼cke noch nicht schlieÃŸen konnte. Und das Zeitfenster, in dem man agieren kann, wird immer kleiner. Anspannung und Entscheidungsdruck wachsen. TÃ¤glich werden neue Szenarien durchgespielt. Durch eine hohe Transfereinnahme ist beispielsweise der Transfer eines Spielers mÃ¶glich, den man schon vorher verpflichten wollte, aber aus wirtschaftlichen GrÃ¼nden nicht konnte. Dieser Spieler ist aber vielleicht grade kurz vor dem Vertragsabschluss mit einem anderen Club. Es kann zugehen wie in einem aufgeregten Taubenschlag. Solch ein Transfer-Finale fordert permanentes Umdenken. Nehmen wir die Bayern als Beispiel. . Was tut sich bei den MÃ¼nchnern im Mittelfeld? Bleibt Gravenberch oder nicht? Wenn er wechselt: Per Leihe oder Verkauf? Nutzt man daraus resultierende Einnahmen und die Gehaltsersparnis, um vielleicht den Tuchel-Wunsch nach einer zusÃ¤tzlichen Sechs zu erfÃ¼llen? Was bedeutet dies fÃ¼r Kimmich, Goretzka und Laimer und fÃ¼r die gesamte Balance im Kader? Wenn man mÃ¶gliche Transfereinnahmen und Gehaltsersparnisse fÃ¼r beide zusammenrechnet, dÃ¼rfte ein Gesamtvolumen von Ã¼ber 80 Millionen Euro zusammenkommen. FC Bayern: â€Geld ist vorhanden und der Positionsbedarf ist groÃŸâ€œ Es wÃ¤re dann jedem klar: Geld ist vorhanden und der Positionsbedarf ist groÃŸ. Dadurch werden mÃ¶gliche AblÃ¶sen nicht geringer. GrundsÃ¤tzlich sind die Bayern aber in einer starken Position und werden kein Geschenkpaket schnÃ¼ren und nur verkaufen, wenn man interessante Alternativen umsetzen kann und zudem wirtschaftlich oder sportlich profitiert. Dreesen, HoeneÃŸ, Rummenigge und Neppe sind erfahrene Dealmaker und kennen das GeschÃ¤ft aus dem Effeff. Sicher ist eines, die KÃ¶pfe werden rauchen und natÃ¼rlich hat auch Thomas Tuchel klare Vorstellungen. Ich glaube, dass noch Unvorhergesehenes passiert, es wirtschaftliche Megadeals und mÃ¤chtig Bewegung geben wird. Bei den Saudis geht die Transferperiode noch weitere drei Wochen und das kann fÃ¼r mÃ¤chtig Unruhe sorgen. newsArray.title: â€˜One Of The Bestâ€™ â€“ Manchester United Star Pleads For Teammate To Stay
creator: Aaron Hindhaugh
newsArray.description: Manchester Unitedâ€™s Ella Toone has spoken to Sky Sports about how she hopes to see Mary Earps stay amid interest from other clubs around Europe. Earps has risen to stardom over the past couple of years and she largely has Sarina Wiegman to thank for that because prior to her arrival as the England manager, [â€¦]
newsArray.content: Earps has risen to stardom over the past couple of years and she largely has Sarina Wiegman to thank for that because prior to her arrival as the England manager, it was Ellie Roebuck who was the regular number one for the Lionesses and seen as the future to stopper for years to come. However, an injury to Roebuck and a huge amount of faith from Wiegman later and Earps is now widely regarded as the best goalkeeper in Womenâ€™s football and even has the trophy to prove it having been voted the best between the sticks earlier this year. Most Read on Euro Weekly News Ella Toone hopeful of Mary Earps staying at Man United While starring for England and in the Womenâ€™s Super League, it has certainly been over the last two summer tournaments in which Earps has spent the show and proven to the world just how good she is with the ball at her feet and also keeping it out of her net. Therefore, itâ€™s no surprise that an unnamed Champions League club lodged a world record bid for Earps earlier in the transfer window, just a few days after England had experienced World Cup heartache out in Australia at the hands of Spain, making it the second record bid have received this year following bid for Alessia Russo. "She's been unbelievable" Ella Toone has her fingers crossed that Mary Earps will be staying at Manchester United! ğŸ¤ğŸ”´ â€” Sky Sports WSL (@SkySportsWSL) rejected the bid out of hand and that unnamed side are yet to return with an improved offer for Earps, and her teammate, Ella Toone, is hopeful that the impressive shot-stopper will remain in Manchester. She said: â€œSheâ€™s one of the best, sheâ€™s been unbelievable in the past two tournaments for England and sheâ€™s had an unbelievable season for [Man] United. Eaprs is set to attract further attention â€œSo, sheâ€™s going to have interest in her, sheâ€™s one of the best keepers in the world at the moment. â€œIâ€™m glad weâ€™re hopefully getting to keep her and hopefully we have a successful season with her and she brings a lot of success to the team.â€ From Tooneâ€™s short interview, it appears as though sheâ€™s got no inkling of Earps edging for a move away from which will be huge news for the Red Devils as they get set to embark on their first ever Champions League season. Thank you for taking the time to read this article. newsArray.title: Kouta suggests midfield move for Curnow; Peter Daicos says Nick might have played an elimination final
creator: Peter Ryan
newsArray.description: Carlton premiership hero Anthony Koutoufides would love to see the Blues unleash dual Coleman medallist Charlie Curnow in the midfield during the finals, as tickets to the Blues-Swans elimination final sold out in just hours.
newsArray.content: In todayâ€™s AFL Briefing, your daily wrap of footy news Collingwood legend Peter Daicos doesnâ€™t expect the huge gap between games to be an issue for his son Nick when he returns for the Magpiesâ€™ second final. Nathan Jones says the 2023 Demons are motivated to add a missing piece of the puzzle by holding the premiership cup at the MCG in front of long-suffering fans. Anthony Koutoufides says the Blues should consider unleashing Charlie Curnow in the midfield. Koutoufides says Blues should consider midfield move for Curnow Peter Ryan Carlton premiership hero Anthony Koutoufides would love to see the Blues unleash dual Coleman medallist Charlie Curnow in the midfield during the finals series as they attempt to win the premiership from fifth spot. Carlton star Charlie Curnow. Credit: AFL Photos Koutoufides transformed the role of an AFL midfielder when he dominated the 1995 finals series, helping the Blues to their most recent premiership. He was the best player in the game for a period, with opponents unable to curb his rare combination of power and speed. He said he sees the same traits in Curnow and believes the Coleman medallist would strike fear into the opposition if he was swung into the midfield. â€œI would love to see him play in the midfield to see what he could do. If he could run around the wing or the midfield there would be no one in the competition that would be able to keep up with him,â€ Koutoufides said. â€œThen of course if you throw in his high marking and the capability of running forward also. â€œHe is one of those scary propositions that if you were to unleash him come finals time â€¦ he would be scary running around the football field.â€ Curnow sealed his second consecutive Coleman Medal on Sunday when he kicked two goals in the first quarter against the Giants and finished the home-and-away season on 78 goals, 14 more than the previous season when he played one less game. Next Friday night against Sydney he will play his 50th consecutive game after missing nearly two years with a knee injury. â€œI still believe heâ€™s got another level or two to go,â€ Koutoufides said. The former Carlton champion said the race for the flag was open and that the Blues had enough talent to scare the other teams in the finals. The Bluesâ€™ elimination final against the Swans sold out just hours after tickets went on sale on Wednesday. Tickets for the match, which will be played at the MCG, first went on sale at 10am on Wednesday. The AFL announced the match was sold out just after 4pm the same day. â€œShould further tickets become available as a result of unused allocations, they will be released via Ticketek on Wednesday, September 6 at 11am,â€ the AFL said. Long lay-off no worries for Nick Daicos Peter Ryan Collingwood legend Peter Daicos doesnâ€™t expect the huge gap between games to be an issue for his son Nick when he returns for the Magpiesâ€™ second final. Nick Daicos was ruled out for more than a month when he suffered a hairline fracture in his right knee early in August. Nick Daicos wonâ€™t have played since round 21 when he returns for finals Credit: AFL Photos Peter Daicos said he did not expect Nick to play in the qualifying final against Melbourne despite coach Craig McRae keeping the door slightly ajar for an earlier-than expected return. The club had been firm that he would not be available in the first week of the finals, but McRae told Fox Footy on Tuesday night he preferred not to rule the slim possibility out completely. The senior Daicos was confident that Nick would not be hampered by time out of the game when he does make his return, saying Nick had slotted in fine at the start of his AFL career, despite having played very few games in the preceding years due to COVID-19. â€œOne of his good attributes or skill sets is his hard running and if they came off a little bit heâ€™s still going to be up there,â€ Daicos said. He said he sometimes cringes when he sees what is said or written about his son because he knows he would, ideally, prefer to work away in the background. â€œI ask him at times how he is feeling with it and I know him pretty well, so he tells me as it is. He is pretty comfortable with it and he uses a lot of that with self motivation as well,â€ Daicos said. Peter said the thinking around Nickâ€™s selection may have been different if Collingwood didnâ€™t have a double chance. â€œHad it been an elimination [final] there would have been a lot more thinking going into rolling the dice. There is a bigger scalp to be had here and we have to try to get our players to the end of the season, so itâ€™s a management thing.â€ He said McRae would have been keeping his sonâ€™s spirits up as he worked his way through the rehabilitation program. â€œHeâ€™s doing the work and he is keen to get back.â€ The Magpies finished on top of the ladder but will go in to the qualifying final as only slight favourites against the Demons, with Daicos saying the premiership race is wide open. He praised the efforts of his other son, Josh, who has been a key player on the wing in 2023. He was one of 40 players nominated for the All-Australian team. Loading â€œIâ€™m pleased for Josh because of the amount of work [he has done],â€ Daicos said. â€œOne of the other things that is coming through now with his maturity is his leadership. He is just growing in that part of his game.â€ Peter kicked 97 goals in the Magpiesâ€™ breakthrough 1990 premiership-winning season and is a member of the Australian Football Hall of Fame. He said missing games wonâ€™t help Nickâ€™s Brownlow chances, but it was hard to predict who would poll votes anyway. MCG premiership motivating Melbourne: Jones Peter Ryan Melbourne great Nathan Jones says the 2023 Demons are motivated to add a missing piece of the puzzle by holding the premiership cup at the MCG in front of long-suffering fans. The Demons won their drought-breaking premiership at Optus Stadium in Perth with most of their diehard fans forced to watch the win on television while stuck in a COVID-19 lockdown in Melbourne. The Demons want to hold a cup up at the MCG Credit: Getty Images Jones, who played a key role in lifting the club from the doldrums to become premiers, said there â€œwas absolutely no doubtâ€ his former teammates wanted to fill that gap this season. â€œThat has been the motivating factor,â€ Jones said. â€œIt was the only real thing missing from 2021, the fact that Melbourne was in COVID lockdown and none of our supporters could get across there [to Perth]. â€œThey are absolutely driven to get back to being part of a grand final game again at the MCG and being able to hold up the cup officially in front of all our diehard fans that have been through so much for such a long period of time, for 50-plus years.â€ Jones said it was devastating to watch Jake Melksham hurt his knee in the final round, denying him a chance to play in a potential flag after he watched the 2021 game from the sidelines. He said he would still play a role in September but clearly his future was up in the air after he was diagnosed with an ACL rupture. Melkshamâ€™s absence has created a gap inside 50 at the Demons. Jones said he would select premiership forward Tom McDonald over makeshift forward Brodie Grundy, although he admitted it was a tough decision for the match committee. â€œHeâ€™s proved in that forward role, in particular,â€ Jones said. â€œI also think the way Max [Gawn] plays his best footy is spending a large chunk of time as the key ruckman and pinch hitting down [forward] for small periods of time.â€ Jones is optimistic about the Demonsâ€™ chances, saying they are timing their run well this season as they build towards their best form.
